entry.title: PMDG Unveils Operations Center 3.0
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS20. PMDG recently unveiled its new Operations Center 3.0, a complete overhaul of their product management application, which has been roughly the same since 2017. The new application features a fresh design, additional diagnostic tools, in-software add-on installation, streamlined livery handling, and much more. The rollout from OC2 to OC3 will be gradual, with the 777F being the first product to transition to the new suite. People who might be interested in checking the new Operations Center are instructed to uninstall their 777F, download OC3 from here, install it, enter their PMDG credentials, and then install the 777F from there. The 777-300ER will follow shortly (within the next few days), and once it is available, the procedure is expected to be the same as the one listed above. â PMDG will also provide full documentation on operating the new Operations Center, which is said to be available âin time for the weekend.â â As they move their entire product line to OC3, installers will no longer be available once the rollout is complete, as they want people managing their product line straight from OC3. â They also hint at making a new 777 available soon, with âmore news on that on the next update.â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon! â

entry.title: PMDG Shares Development Update for MSFS 20/24
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. PMDG has recently released another development update regarding nearly all of its products for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. Key highlights from the update include the announcement of a release window for the upcoming PMDG 777-200ER for both MSFS 2020 and 2024, as well as a rollout sequence for the product line tailored for MSFS 2024. The development team has announced that the 777-200ER will be released simultaneously for both Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, with the launch expected between April 16th and April 29th. The add-on will feature different engine types, including the GE90-92 and the Rolls Royce Trent 892. Additionally, it will include a new generation of sound packages. There will be only one package available, which will include versions for both simulators. With the release of the first PMDG product for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 approaching, the team has announced a rollout schedule for their product lineup. The expected release dates are as follows:Â â - The 777-200ER is anticipated between April 16th and April 29th. - The DC-6 is scheduled for early May. - The 777F and 777-300ER are expected to be released between mid and late May. - The 777-200LR will be available from late May to early June. - The 737NGs do not yet have an estimated arrival time, as their conversion to 2024 has not yet begun. The team has announced that the 747 product lines will only be developed for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, and not for 2020. Additionally, the PMDG Operations Center 3 has been expanded to include the 777F and 777-300ER. The DC-6 and all 737NG variants will be added very soon. Once these aircraft are added to OC3, they will be removed from OC2. entry.title: SimCoders and PAE Releases Beechcraft Bonanza G36 for X-Plane 12
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. SimCoders and PAE have recently collaborated to release the Beechcraft Bonanza G36 for X-Plane 12. This general aviation aircraft, renowned for its reliability and performance, has been meticulously recreated for the simulator with study-level detail. The Beechcraft Bonanza has a rich history. Manufactured by the US company Beechcraft, the first variant, the Model 35 Bonanza, was introduced in 1947 and produced until 1982. This model featured a distinctive v-tail design. In 1960, the Model 33 Debonair/Bonanza was introduced. It featured a conventional tail and remained in production until 1995. The latest variant is the Model 36 Bonanza, which was introduced in 1968 and is still in production today. The Model 36 is an extended version of the Model 33 Debonair/Bonanza. As of 2024, a total of 18,546 Beechcraft Bonanzas have been built. This general aviation aircraft is popular worldwide and can be found in many locations across the globe. The aircraft is equipped with a variety of features, including a fully simulated IO-550 engine, a custom fuel system, a custom G1000, realistic 3D modelling, REP features, and much more. The newly released aircraft is now available for purchase at the X-Plane.Org Software Store for $45.00. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: Lata Voadora Releases Campo de Marte Airport for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Lata Voadora has recently released their rendition of Campo de Marte Airport (SBMT) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, the first airport ever to open in Sao Paulo, Brazil.Â It was founded in 1929 (95 years ago), and its first few years were far from glorious: it was bombarded during the Constitutionalist Revolution of 1932. That did not stop it from having its commercial debut a year later, with scheduled flights to Sao Carlos and Sao Jose do Rio Preto, Ribeirao Preto, and Uberaba. It was Sao Paulo's main airport until the opening of Congonhas Airport in 1936, which was bigger and less flood-prone (Campo de Marte had been flooded in 1929).Â Nowadays, it mainly handles helicopters and general aviation and still hosts a nearly hundred-year-old flying club.Â The traffic figures are around 60,000 aircraft operations per year, a massive drop from a decade ago when they reached almost twice that amount. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with custom ground textures, a high-detail model of the passenger terminal and its interior, custom landclass buildings, custom hangars, and much more. It's available on their website for roughly $7. Due to popular demand, an MSFS 2020-compatible version is in the works and set to be released by the end of the month. entry.title: Fly2High Releases Fresno Yosemite International Airport V2 for MSFS 20/24
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Fly2High has recently released version V2 of Fresno Yosemite International Airport (KFAT) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. Located in Fresno, California, this airport serves both military and civilian flights, accommodating nearly 2.7 million passengers each year. The airport originally opened as a military airfield in 1942, with construction of a passenger terminal beginning in 1946. Once the terminal was completed in 1948, both Trans World Airlines and United Airlines commenced operations at the airport. In 1959, work began on a new, larger passenger terminal, which was completed and opened for use in 1962. The current air traffic control (ATC) tower was finished in 1961. The terminal underwent an expansion in 1978. After renovations in 2006 made it capable of receiving international arrivals, international service began that same year. Today, the airport serves several airlines, including Alaska Airlines, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and United Airlines, handling nearly 2.7 million passengers annually and just under 87,000 aircraft movements. The V2 version includes several features such as highly detailed models, high-resolution textures, and custom jetways. It also boasts a completely redesigned ground layout, new surrounding buildings, and enhancements to the main terminal when compared to the V1 version. The newly released version V2 is now available on SimMarket for approximately $18.18 and requires around 1.49 GB of disk space. For V1 owners, the V2 version is offered as a free upgrade. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: FlightSim Studio Releases B727 Passenger for MSFS 2020
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS20. FlightSim Studio has just released the much-anticipated passenger variant of the Boeing 727 for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020. Following the release of the cargo variant last summer, users can now take to the skies with the passenger version of this three-engined aircraft. The first Boeing 727 entered service in 1964. Developed after the larger Boeing 707, this aircraft was designed to meet the demand for short-haul flights. There were two passenger variants: the Boeing 727-100 and the longer Boeing 727-200. Additionally, a cargo version of the aircraft was introduced. The Boeing 727 was in production from 1962 to 1984, with a total of 1,832 units built. It has been used by various airlines worldwide across commercial, government, military, and private sectors. The aircraft became an icon thanks to its distinctive three-engine design, making it recognizable around the globe. The FlightSim Studio B727 Passenger is packed with features that enhance the flying experience. The exterior boasts detailed PBR textures, custom animations, 3D lighting, and a variety of custom liveries. The interior includes a fully equipped cockpit designed for passenger operations, a custom cabin, tailored night lighting, and an extended EFB (Electronic Flight Bag). â The flight dynamics have been developed by a real pilot, ensuring a high level of realism. System-wise, the aircraft is equipped with a comprehensive flight engineer panel, a custom SP-150 autopilot, and custom logic for the APU, GPU, generators, and more. For navigation, users can choose from five options: classic, retro, modern standard, modern realism, and futuristic. The sound package accurately replicates the JT8D-9 engine, contributing to the immersive experience.Â â The add-on aims to be a detailed and authentic recreation of the iconic airliner. The newly released Boeing 727 - Passenger Edition requires 5 GB of storage space and is now available at Aerosoft for approximately $45.45. Owners of the Boeing 727 - Freighter Edition qualify for a 20% upgrade discount. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: Parallel 42 Releases ChasePlane for MSFS 2020
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS20. After nearly a month of being a Club 42 exclusive for testing and refinement purposes, Parallel 42âs ChasePlane is now available to the public. This brings their advanced physics-based camera system to Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020. For the unfamiliar, ChasePlane was originally released in 2016 for Microsoft Flight Simulator X, later being made compatible with Prepar3d and rapidly becoming the de facto camera application for ESP-based simulators at the time. It would only be natural for them to develop it for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 when that came about, but technical limitations have made that impossible until very recently, which is why itâs only a thing now, almost five years after the simulatorâs release.Â The add-on features highly realistic physics-based camera behavior based on extensive research and real-world pilot footage. This warrants realistic motion that dynamically responds to the environment, embracing the flight model rather than altering it. Pilots can feel the vibration during the take-off roll, the rush of turbulence, and the fluid shifts during maneuvers. â As previously mentioned, a subscription system will no longer be required to store and share your settings in their cloud. Parallel 42 will now offer the service as a courtesy and take the costs upon themselves. â Furthermore, ChasePlane 2020 owners will be entitled to a free upgrade once the Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 version is available.Â â The add-on is available in their store for $30.00.
